we can see the transition is going to be

it's a big transition we're not quite
sure the best way to make it we've got a

getting into the 16-bit market and so

where the main processor was the new

and given the cost point they were

through a little bit of rework became

it's fun people enjoy it
so the machine had to do a set of things

they also were quite particular about
the programming language and BBC basic
emerged as a compromise between you know
Rogers experience of building basics for
earlier icon machines and the BBC's
requirement for a language which was
really rather nicer and cleaner than a

as an optional upgrade to your BBC micro
you could plug in
a couple of linear predictive coding
speech chips that would give you a

Kenneth Kendall I think was was the the

it was a crew it was a creative tension
I mean it wasn't always easy we didn't

they were they were willing to negotiate

being unreasonable about it they were on

supply switch mode power supplies

thought the radio spectrum was their

that that created interference in their

this turned out to be a very bad idea

Royal transformers and we made them as

but it was only after we've been in

factor
I'm by Aztek in Hong Kong a couple of

we had to multiplex some bits of address

into the column and the chip we used for
that
the national semiconductor 81 or less 95
okay the numbers engraved in my brain
this was quite a simple chip it was a
multiplexer with a tri-state output and
many other suppliers came along and said
we've got a chip that's an exact

that we didn't know why the national

that's the kind of thing you worry about
that the other memorable feature of the
BBC micro is that the poor 6502 s data
bus was seriously overloaded there were
so many peripherals on the machine that
if you worked out how much capacitance
it was driving it was way out of spec
and when we built the first PCB
prototype it didn't work and we
discovered and this is not unusual in
this electronic so if you put your
finger in a certain place on the board
it started working well it's just just
sort of damping oscillations or
something who knows what it's doing
anyway I didn't have enough fingers to
stick one on each of the micros we were
going to build but there is a little
resistor pack across the data bus with 8
resistors pulling the eight data lines
up I think which is the engineer's
finger and again we've no idea why it's
necessary but a million and a half
machines later it was still working so
nobody asked any questions when I
compared the standards to which we

still astonished that the BBC micro
established this reputation for being

fingering the air engineering and

perhaps victory over engineering in a

oh it was not over engineered if you
